raw_text:
Howard and Blair tax pledge clash
 
 Tony Blair has said voters will have to wait for Labour's manifesto to see if the party has plans to increase tax.
 
 The premier was responding to a challenge from Tory leader Michael Howard who said Labour would raise taxes in its post-election Budget. Mr Blair derided Tory claims they could cut £35bn in "wasteful spending" saying the party had got its sums wrong. The two political leaders clashed just days after the opening salvoes of the pre-election period. Mr Howard told MPs that "every independent expert" from the International Monetary Fund to the Institute of Fiscal Studies had suggested the "government was spending more than it is raising and a Labour chancellor would have to put up taxes". Mr Blair replied: "I think they are wrong for this very simple reason: that the Treasury forecasts on the economy have been proven right." The Tories on Monday highlighted their plans for tax cuts worth £4bn, although the specific taxes to be cut have not been announced.
 
 They also spelled out their plans for reduced government borrowing and more spending on key services. Labour and the Liberal Democrats have said the party's sums do not add up and claim it would cut frontline services. But Mr Howard said voters faced a clear choice at the next election between more waste and more tax under Labour and Tory value for money and lower taxes. The Liberal Democrats have also launched their pre-election platform, with leader Charles Kennedy saying his party was the "authentic opposition", particularly on the Iraq war, council tax and university tuition fees. Labour hit back at the Tory proposals even before their publication with election coordinator Alan Milburn accusing Mr Howard of producing a "fraudulent prospectus".
llama3.2:1b: Howard and Blair clash over tax pledge during pre-election period.
Tony Blair denies Labour's plans to increase taxes in its post-election Budget, saying Tories are correct that Labour would raise taxes if they had done their sums correctly.
The two leaders have differing forecasts of the economy.
The Tory plan includes £4bn worth of tax cuts, but specific taxes will not be announced yet.
Labour claims the party's forecast for government spending and borrowing has been wrong.
Tories also highlight plans to reduce government borrowing and spend more on key services.
Labor and Liberal Democrats disagree with these plans, accusing them of being value for money and reducing frontline services.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair said Labour's manifesto will show if they plan to increase taxes, responding to Michael Howard's claim that they would raise taxes in the post-election Budget.
Mr Blair derided Tory claims, saying their estimates were incorrect and that the Treasury's forecasts have proven right.
The Tories announced plans for £4bn in tax cuts, while Labour claims their proposals add up but cut frontline services.
gemma2:2b: Tony Blair denies that Labour will raise taxes in its manifesto.
Michael Howard claims Labour would increase taxes in their post-election budget, predicting £35 billion in savings by cutting government spending.
The Tories have released plans for tax cuts worth £4 billion and reduced borrowing, while Labour contends the plan is fiscally irresponsible, leading to potential service cuts.
The Liberal Democrats present a platform focused on opposition to the Iraq war and council tax, arguing they are the "authentic opposition".
qwen2.5:0.5b: Howard and Blair have clashed over their tax pledges in the pre-election period.
Blair has suggested that voters will need to wait for Labour's manifesto to see if they plan to increase taxes, while Howard claims Labour would raise £35 billion in its post-election Budget.
The two political leaders also challenged each other over plans for reduced government borrowing and cuts to frontline services.
They outlined their plans for tax reductions, spending on key services, as well as reducing the deficit and lowering taxes overall.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Tony Blair challenged Michael Howard to produce evidence that Labour would cut £35bn in "wasteful spending," claiming Labour's forecasts on economic growth were accurate.
Howard countered, stating experts unanimously agreed Labour needed to raise taxes due to higher than expected government spending and forecasted deficits.
Both leaders clashed amid pre-election campaigning, with Blair emphasizing his party's fiscal discipline and commitment to reducing waste.
qwen2.5:3b: Tony Blair dismissed Michael Howard's claims that Labour would increase taxes in its post-election Budget.
Howard accused Labour of planning to raise taxes and claimed independent experts supported his argument.
Blair countered by stating Treasury forecasts were correct, suggesting that Labour would have no choice but to raise taxes.
Meanwhile, the Tories proposed £4bn in tax cuts for next election, though specific taxes had not been announced.
The Liberal Democrats presented their pre-election platform, emphasizing their authenticity on issues like the Iraq war and university tuition fees.
Labour criticized the Tory plans, accusing them of promoting waste and increasing taxation.

The summary should preserve key ideas and details:

1.
The Premier is responding to a challenge from Tory leader Michael Howard who said Labour would raise taxes in its post-election Budget.
The premier was saying that Labour would increase taxes in their post-election budget, but the Tories claim they could cut £35bn in "wasteful spending" and that Labour would have to put up taxes.
The two political leaders clashed just days after the opening salvoes of the pre-election period.

Labour hit back at the Tory proposals even before their publication with election coordinator Alan Milburn accusing Mr Howard of producing a "fraudulent prospectus".
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
Howard and Blair tax pledge clash  
Tony Blair has claimed voters will wait for Labour’s manifesto to assess tax plans.

Tony Blair criticized Conservative leader Michael Howard's claims about "wasteful spending," pointing out that Labour forecasts were flawed, while stating that "more taxes" would not justify their claims.
The conflict arose after the pre-election period.
Blair used expert opinions to argue against Labour’s spending, while Howard critical of Tory arguments for credibility.
tinyllama:1.1b: Tony Blair responded to Michael Howard's comments on the Labour manifesto, declaring that the party had got its sums wrong and said they would need to increase taxes in their post-electoral Budget.

In response, Howard accused the Labour Party of making "spineless" promises and being "wasteful spenders", while saying that "every independent expert" from the International Monetary Fund to the Institute of Fiscal Studies had suggested the government was spending more than it was raising, leading to concerns of increased taxes.

Meanwhile, Labour and the Liberal Democrats have promised more services on a frontline basis, with the Liberal Democrats claiming that the Labour Party's sums do not add up and that they would cut frontline services if elected.
In contrast, Howard said voters were faced with a clear choice at the next election between "more waste" and lower taxes.
tinydolphin:1.1b: A prominent political disagreement has arisen between Michael Howard, leader of the Conservatives and Tony Blair, leader of Labour.
The two leaders have been exchanging criticism regarding taxation policies.
Mr. Howard claims that Labour will raise taxes in its upcoming Budget, while Mr. Blair asserts that the Tories are not doing enough to reduce wasteful spending.

This disagreement has been an important aspect of the campaign for the upcoming election, with voters having to decide whether they want a party willing to increase taxes or one that can provide better value for their money.
phi:2.7b: The two political leaders, Tony Blair and Michael Howard, disagreed on whether to increase taxes in Labour's post-election Budget.
While Blair dismissed claims that taxes would have to be raised, Howard argued that the government was spending more than it was raising and a Labour chancellor would have to put up taxes.
The Conservatives highlighted their plans for tax cuts worth £4bn, but Labour and Liberal Democrats claimed that the party's sums did not add up and accused them of cutting frontline services.
Kennedy announced his party's plan to provide value for money and lower taxes, while Labour hit back at the Tory proposals by accusing Howard of producing a fraudulent prospectus.
orca-mini:3b: Tony Blair and Michael Howard have disagreed on Labour's plans to increase taxes in its post-election Budget.

Blair rejected the idea that Labour would raise taxes, while Howard said every independent expert has predicted the government's spending is higher than its revenue and a Labour chancellor would have to put up taxes.
Blair replied that the Treasury forecasts on the economy have been proven correct.
The two political leaders clashed just days after the opening salvoes of the pre-election period, with Blair deriding Howard's claim that Tory plans include tax cuts worth £4bn.
They also highlighted their own party's promises to reduce government borrowing and increase spending on key services.
hermes3:3b: Howard and Blair tax clash: Blair refuses to confirm if Labour will raise taxes before manifesto.

Howard highlighted plans for tax cuts worth £4bn and reduced government borrowing, while Labour and Liberal Democrats argue that their sums do not add up and claim they would cut frontline services.
The upcoming election offers a choice between more waste under Labour or more tax and lower taxes under the Tories.

Blair defended Treasury forecasts, arguing they had been accurate.
The Tories proposed £4bn in tax cuts but did not specify which taxes would be reduced, while also pledging lower government borrowing and increased spending on key services.
Labour and the Liberal Democrats criticized the Tory plans as unrealistic and harmful to public services.

Meanwhile, Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy positioned his party as the "authentic opposition," particularly on Iraq, council tax, and tuition fees.

stablelm2:1.6b: Premier Tony Blair has said that Labour will not reveal its plans for increased taxes until the party's manifesto is released during the election.

In response to claims from Tory leader Michael Howard, who suggested Labour would raise taxes in their post-election Budget, Mr. Blair argued that Howard's claims were baseless due to accurate Treasury forecasts on the economy.
The two leaders clashed after the opening period of pre-election discussions.

Meanwhile, the Tories outlined plans for £4bn worth of tax cuts and increased government spending on essential services; however, Labour and the Liberal Democrats claim their financial proposals don
To sum it up: Tony Blair refutes claims from Michael Howard that Labour would raise taxes in its post-election Budget, insisting that accurate economic forecasts prove otherwise.
Meanwhile, the Tories propose £4bn worth of tax cuts and increased government spending, while Labour and the Liberal Democrats argue that their proposals will negatively impact frontline services.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Tony Blair and Michael Howard, leaders of the incumbent Conservative Party and opposition Labour Party respectively, have engaged in a pre-election tax debate.
Blair dismissed claims by Howard that a future Labour government would raise taxes to balance spending, citing Treasury forecasts as proof of accurate financial management.
Meanwhile, the Conservatives announced plans for £4bn in tax cuts and reduced borrowing, promising better value for money and lower taxes.
Labour countered that these proposals would lead to service cuts, questioning the accuracy of their opponents' economic projections.
The Liberal Democrats joined the fray, emphasizing their role as a genuine opposition on issues like Iraq, council tax, and university fees.
Labour criticized the Conservatives' prospectus as "fraudulent."
